newsitem.title: USA: 3Dfx may lose Sega contract to NEC.
newsitem.headline: 3Dfx may lose Sega contract to NEC.

text.p: 3Dfx Interactive Inc on Monday said Sega Enterprises Ltd had not yet decided whether it would use 3Dfx's computer chip in its next-generation video game console.

Sega "at this time has not determined the makeup of its new Sega console," said Chris Kramer, a 3Dfx spokesman. Sega told 3Dfx that "no decisions have been made" on whether the video game company will use chips from 3Dfx or a rival chip maker.

The speculation about the Sega contract comes at a bad time for 3Dfx, which went public recently. Much of the company's market value comes from a huge contract for supplying Sega with chips for each of the company's video game consoles in the works.
3Dfx's stock was hammered Monday when Microprocessor Report, an industry newsletter, reported in its July 14 issue that Sega was dumping 3Dfx's chip in favor of an offering from NEC Corp.
Officials at Sega and NEC could not be reached immediately for comment.
In early afternoon trading, 3Dfx shares were down 4-5/8, or 29 percent, at 11-1/2 on Nasdaq trading of 2.14 million. The stock was among the most active on Nasdaq.
